justification: The article states that "in the classic selective attention experiment – the Invisible Gorilla Test – whether the participants notice the gorilla reflects a phenomenological conclusion related to attention."
It notes that "A common experimental method used to test predictive coding is repetition suppression," describing how neural responses are monitored while the same stimulus is repeatedly presented.

The paper mentions that "in recent experiments involving mismatch negativity (MMN), researchers found that informing the subjects of the target greatly influenced the experimental results," using MMN to probe expectation mechanisms.

The authors remark that "there are multiple ways that the mind measures egocentric distance perception" and cite Dong et al. (2023) titled "Methods for measuring egocentric distance perception in visual modality."
